posts.title: Migrants, Travelers, and Storytellers: Albanian-American Encounters in the Early 20th Century
posts.text: A guest post by Smoki Musaraj, Associate Professor of Anthropology at Ohio University, who spent time at NYPL as a Short-Term Fellow.

posts.title: Adapting and Commodifying Slavic Folklore in Russia and the West
posts.text: NYPL's extensive collection of translations of Slavic folk and fairy tales shows a longstanding fascination with Slavic folklore in Russia and the West that the current young adult and popular markets are expanding upon.

posts.title: Revelations from the Archive: An Update on the Apocalypse in New York Public Library, MA 15
posts.text: Demons fleeing statues, corpses reanimating, stones transformed into gold: who knew that seeing a seven-headed beast would not be the most freakish thing to happen to someone? Yet these incidents and more are present in the several illuminated Apocalypses held in the NYPL’s Manuscripts and Rare Books collections.

posts.title: From Integration to Liberation: Growing Into the Black Power Movement
posts.text: Short-Term Research Fellowship Recipient Autumn Allen describes the many resources she used to study the youth of the Black Power movement.
